'''Seuthopolis''' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Σευθόπολις) was an ancient [[hellenistic]]-type<ref>Europe Between the Oceans: 9000 BC-AD 1000 by [[Barry Cunliffe|Barry W. Cunliffe]], 2008,page 331,""... The most sophisticated was the capital, Seuthopolis, founded by the Odrysian king Seuthes III in c.32o BC. The town was laid out entirely in the style of a Hellenistic city...""</ref> city founded<ref>A History of the Hellenistic World: 323 - 30 BC R. Malcolm Errington, 2008,"...in founding a city which he named after himself, Seuthopolis (SEG 42, 661). ..."</ref> by the [[Thracians|Thracian]] king [[Seuthes III]] between 325-315 BC and the capital of the [[Odrysian kingdom]].<ref>An Inventory of Archaic and Classical Poleis: An Investigation Conducted by The Copenhagen Polis Centre for the Danish National Research Foundation by Mogens Herman Hansen,2005,page 1336,"Seuthopolis founded c.325-315"</ref>
Its ruins are now located at the bottom of the [[Koprinka Reservoir]] near [[Kazanlak]], [[Stara Zagora Province]], in central [[Bulgaria]].
Several kilometres north of the city is the [[Valley of the Thracian Rulers]] where many magnificent royal tombs are located.
[[File:Seuthopolis City Plan.jpg|thumb|300px|Seuthopolis city plan]] Seuthopolis was not<ref>An Inventory of Archaic and Classical Poleis: An Investigation Conducted by The Copenhagen Polis Centre for the Danish National Research Foundation by Mogens Herman Hansen,2005,page 888,"It was meant to be a polis but this was no reason to think that it was anything other than a native settlement"</ref> a true [[polis]], but rather the seat of Seuthes and his court. His palace had a dual role, functioning also as a sanctuary of the [[Cabeiri]], the gods of [[Samothrace]].<ref>The Princeton Encyclopedia of Classical Sites (eds. Richard Stillwell, William L. MacDonald, Marian Holland McAllister),A Thracian city near the village of Koprinka. It was founded at the end of the 4th c. B.C. by Seuthes III. The large quantity of material discovered during the excavation has shown that Seuthopolis was not only a center of production, but also of commerce. The city rises on a terrace circumscribed on three sides by the Tundza and by one of its tributaries. It was a fortified city of ca. 5 ha with a pentagonal circuit wall 2 m thick and 890 m in perimeter, with a quadrangular tower at each angle. At the N, between two towers, is the principal gate; and at the south are two gates between bastions. The wall is constructed of clay bricks and wood on stone foundations. The city's orthogonal plan is regular, with two large arteries that lead from the gates to the center. The agora is in the NW sector. In the NE zone is a walled and towered trapezoidal area within which is enclosed the palace of the prince and the Sanctuary of the Great Gods of Samothrace. In the houses, which are built with rooms around a court, has been found a type of plaster. Elements of porticos have been found and upper galleries of wood. The houses were furnished with wells and drainage systems with a channel in the center of the street. The influence of Hippodamos is evident, though the democratic distribution of living quarters is lacking. Seuthes III built his city on the site of an earlier settlement, and he also followed the Hellenistic fashion of the Diadochi in giving it his own name. Greek influence is prevalent in the urban elements cited and in decoration such as antefixes, stucco, and incrustation, and in the use of the Doric capital</ref> Most of the space within the city was occupied not by homes but by official structures, the majority of the people living outside the city. It had Thracian and Greek populace.<ref>An Inventory of Archaic and Classical Poleis: An Investigation Conducted by The Copenhagen Polis Centre for the Danish National Research Foundation by Mogens Herman Hansen,2005,page 888</ref> In 281 BC it was sacked by [[Celts]].<ref>The Ancient Celts by [[Barry Cunliffe|Barry W. Cunliffe]],{{ISBN|0-14-025422-6}},2000,page 172</ref>
The dual role of Seuthes' palace (royal court and sanctuary) indicates that Seuthes was a priest–king: the high priest of the Cabeiri among the Odrysian Thracians. According to Seuthopolis’ sign, the sanctuary of [[Dionysus|Dionysius]]/[[Sabazios]] was situated on the square.
The cemetery of Seuthopolis included a number of brick [[Beehive tomb|tholos]] tombs, some covered by [[tumulus|tumuli]], in which the upper-class were interred, sometimes along with their horses. The less affluent were cremated, with modest grave goods laid alongside.
[[File:SeuthesIII tumba Kazanlâk 0771a.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bronze head of King Seuthes III]] The ruins of the city were discovered and excavated in 1948<ref>The Hellenistic Settlements in Europe, the Islands, and Asia Minor by Getzel M. Cohen,1996," The existence of Seuthopolis in Thrace was not known until 1948"</ref> by Bulgarian archeologists during the construction of the [[Georgi Dimitrov]] (later renamed Koprinka) Reservoir. However, it was decided to continue with the construction and flood the dam, leaving Seuthopolis at its bottom.
One of the most important archaeological finds is the so-called "Great inscription" found in 1953 in the palace-citadel. It is written in Greek, which indicates that Thracians were already hellenised in the 3rd century BC. [[File:Seuthopolis inscription BG.jpg|thumb|The "Great Inscription", written in Greek, represents a contract between Odrys and [[Macedonia (ancient kingdom)|Macedonia]].]]
In 2005, Bulgarian architect Zheko Tilev proposed a project to uncover, preserve and reconstruct the city of Seuthopolis (the best preserved Thracian city in Bulgaria) by means of a dam wall surrounding the ruins in the middle of the dam, enabling the site's inscription as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] and making it a tourist destination of world importance. Tourists would be transported to the site by boats. The round wall, 420 metres in [[diameter]], would enable visitors to see the city from 20 metres above and would also feature "hanging gardens", glass lifts, a quay, restaurants, cafés, shops, ateliers, etc. It would be illuminated at night.
The project was donated by the architect to Kazanlak municipality and funds are being raised to begin construction. According to Tilev, it would cost minimum [[Euro|€]]50 million.<sup>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090302154305/http://www.imoti.net/news/news.php?id=1800]</sup> [[File:Lead serpent from Seuthopolis, Kazanlak region, Bulgaria. IV-III century BC.png|thumb|Lead serpent from Seuthopolis, Kazanlak region, Bulgaria.IV-III century BC.]] [[Sevtopolis Peak]] on [[Greenwich Island]] in the [[South Shetland Islands]], [[Antarctica]] is named for Seuthopolis.
[[File:Artificial lake kazanlak.jpg|thumb|Artificial Lake of Kazanlak - Site of the Seuthopolis excavation]]

{{tone|date=April 2017}} {{For|the community service|social artistry}} '''Social practice''' is an art medium focusing on engagement through human interaction and social discourse.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Education for Socially Engaged Art|last=Helguera|first=Pablo|publisher=Jorge Pinto Books|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=22}}</ref> Since people and their relationships form the medium of such works – rather than a particular process of production – social engagement is not only a part of a work’s organization, execution, or continuation, but also an aesthetic in itself: of interaction and development.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=What we Made: conversations on art and social cooperation|last=Finkelpearl|first=Tom|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=Durham|pages=132}}</ref> Socially engaged art aims to create social and/or political change through collaboration with individuals, communities, and institutions in the creation of participatory art.<ref>https://www.artjob.org/content/collaboration-where-art-social-practice-begins</ref> The discipline values the process of a work over any finished product or object.<ref name=":0" />
Artists working in social practice co-create their work with a specific audience or propose critical interventions within existing social systems to inspire debate or catalyze social exchange.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cca.edu/academics/graduate/fine-arts/socialpractices|title=Social Practice Workshop|publisher=California College of the Arts|accessdate= Sep 18, 2014}}</ref> The large overlap between social practice and pedagogy demonstrates the need for art education to embrace collaborative practice.<ref>Sholette, G. (n.d.). “After OWS: social practice art, abstraction, and the limits of the social”. Retrieved April 25, 2013, from http://www.e-flux.com/journal/after-ows-social-practice-art-abstraction-and-the-limits-of-the-social/.</ref> Social practice work focuses on the interaction between the audience, social systems, and the artist through [[aesthetics]], [[ethics]], [[collaboration]], methodology, antagonism, media strategies, and [[social activism]].<ref>http://www.reviewsinculture.com/?r=97</ref> The social interaction component inspires, drives, or, in some instances, completes the project.<ref>http://badatsports.com/2011/social-practice-arts-identity-crisis/</ref> Although projects may incorporate traditional studio media, they are realized in a variety of visual or social forms (depending on variable contexts and participant demographics) such as [[Performance art|performance]], [[Protest art|social activism]], or mobilizing communities towards a common goal.<ref>http://isreview.org/issue/90/critique-social-practice-art</ref> The diversity of approaches pose specific challenges for documenting social practice work, as the aesthetic of human interaction changes rapidly and involves many people simultaneously. Consequently, images frequently fail to do justice to the engagement and interactions that take place during a project.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Artificial Hells: Participatory Art and the politics of Spectatorship|last=Bishop|first=Claire|publisher=Verso Books|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref>
==History of terminology==
Until 2005, the term "social practice" was used in a branch of social theory considering human relationships to each other and to the larger society as "practices". The term "art and social practice" was institutionalized in 2005 with the creation of the Social Practice [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]] concentration at the [[California College of the Arts]],<ref name="Artnews">http://www.artnews.com/2013/10/31/how-to-speak-artspeak-properly/</ref> followed by other institutions of higher education offering similar degrees. Social practice art as a medium has been referenced in the ''New York Times'',<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/24/arts/design/outside-the-citadel-social-practice-art-is-intended-to-nurture.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/07/education/edlife/social-practice-degrees-take-art-to-a-communal-level.html|title=Social Practice Degrees Take Art to a Communal Level|last=Grant|first=Daniel|date=2016-02-05|access-date=2016-02-08|issn=0362-4331|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> ''Artforum'',<ref>http://artforum.com/inprint/issue=201207&id=31944&pagenum=1</ref> ''ArtNews,''<ref name="Artnews" /> and ''Art Practical.''<ref>http://www.artpractical.com/feature/notes_toward_a_non_anthropocentric_social_practice/</ref> As an emerging field, social practice can encompass a variety of terms: public practice,<ref name="OtisGPP">{{Cite web|url=http://www.otis.edu/graduate-public-practice|title=Graduate Public Practice|website=Otis College of Art and Design|access-date=2016-01-30}}</ref> socially engaged art,<ref>http://pablohelguera.net/2011/11/education-for-socially-engaged-art-2011/</ref> [[Community arts|community art]], new-genre public art,<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Mapping-Terrain-New-Genre-Public/dp/0941920305</ref> [[participatory art]], [[Art intervention|interventionist art]], [[Collaboration#occupational examples|collaborative art]],<ref>Bishop, Claire. “The Social Turn: Collaboration and Its Discontents” ''Artforum,'' February 2006, 178-83.</ref> [[relational art]] and dialogical aesthetics.<ref name="Artnews" />
== Characteristics of social practice == Socially engaged art differs from its art historical ancestors in that it is not a specific movement or style, but rather a way of defining a new social order.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Living as Form, Socially Engaged Art from 1991-2011|last=Thompson|first=Nato|publisher=MIT Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=19}}</ref> Thousands of existing social practice projects across the world have taken vastly different approaches to their combination of publics, methodologies, aesthetics, and environments, yet these projects all share an aesthetic of human interaction and development. The end products of such works are not commodities, but rather processes for constructive social change.<ref name=":2" /> Some foundational characteristics of socially engaged art remain consistently relevant to a diverse range of works. For an artist or producer to create a successful social practice work, they must consider the unique context in which they are working, and identify specific characteristics of the community and environment. They must also balance aesthetic and methodology in their work, align the timeline of a project with its purpose: a quick-impact ephemeral work, or the regularity of a longitudinal work.
=== Community and environment === Social practice artists and producers aim to affect their community and environment in a real (rather than symbolic) way that enables social and political change.<ref name=":0" /> Each project is tailored to the community and environment in which it will take place. In social practice the identification of the public, or audience, precedes the project's development.<ref name=":0" /> It is impossible to create a project founded upon engagement and collaboration without first making assumptions as to who will be involved. ''Who'' the artist or producer wishes to engage and ''where'' they wish to engage are therefore core characteristics of socially engaged art.<ref name=":0" />
Environment could be described on two primary levels: the broader community, city, or region; and the immediate space being occupied – a street, museum, studio, or other area. To understand the context in which they are working, artists and producers must develop relationships with individuals, organizations and institutions that intersect many different parts of their community and environment. One theorist makes the comparison between socially engaged art projects to exotic fruit, stating that both “usually travel poorly when “exported” to other locations to be replicated.”<ref name=":0" /> The community and environment are therefore not merely external influencers on a specific project – they are inherent characteristics.
=== Aesthetics and methodology === For much of art history, a work's aesthetic has been upheld as the primary measure of its quality. The 20<sup>th</sup> century broadened the public understanding of art to consider concept and process alongside aesthetic, and by the new millennium the tables had turned to emphasize process over product: one of the defining characteristics of socially engaged art. Process is determined by method; thus social practice producers and artists are often more concerned with the methodology rather than the aesthetic of their work. Many argue that social practice has created a new aesthetic of its own: an aesthetic of human interaction and development that is based not on spectatorship but on participation.<ref name=":1" /> This aesthetic captures the diverse methods employed by socially engaged art and encompasses not only traditional methods of painting, photography, architecture, and performance; but also nontraditional forms borrowed from other disciplines, such as festivals, conferences, schools, and protests.
Aesthetics are typically hierarchical, highly subjective, and greatly determined by external influencers, such as the imagery of a given culture, or the relationship between appearance and market value.<ref name=":2" /> To escape these external influencers, aesthetics can also be defined in terms of “aesthesis,” an autonomous realm of experience and judgment that cannot be reduced to logic, reason or morality but is of great importance to humankind.<ref name=":2" /> Aesthetics have the capacity to critique our beliefs and values by restructuring our perception of the world. Their application can achieve one of the core aims of socially engaged art: the definition of a new social order characterized by engagement and participation.
Methodology in socially engaged art refers to the set of practices used throughout the process and production of a project. The method is no longer a means to an end, but an end within itself: the experience of creation and experimentation is a central element of social practice.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Education for Socially Engaged Art|last=Helguera|first=Pablo|publisher=Verso Books|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=2}}</ref> While aesthetics reframe ideas and beliefs outside of the disciplines in which we have accepted them, methodology takes the frameworks of those disciplines to produce new aesthetics. Socially engaged art has embraced conferences, urban regeneration projects, pedagogical projects, and protests, which are all frameworks borrowed from other disciplines.
While aesthetics and methodology can have conflicting interests, there are important reasons why artists and producers should seek to integrate the two. Methodology will engage the public, but aesthetics will play a large role in determining how a project is interpreted. While aesthetics and methodology can have conflicting interests, there are important reasons why artists and producers should seek to integrate the two. Ultimately, the two can work together to enhance each other: the aesthetic value of a project can increase its social function, while the method can heighten the aesthetic experience through public engagement.<ref>{{Cite book|title=What We Made: Conversations on art and social cooperations|last=Finkelpearl|first=Tom|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=Durham|pages=346}}</ref>
=== Longevity vs. ephemerality === The method and aesthetic adopted in social practice work is greatly influenced by intended timeline. Length determines the type of social and/or political change the artist aims to achieve, the types of dialogue created, and the ways in which an individual can engage with a work. The length of a project is also extremely situational. Some projects aim to have an immediate impact, while others prefer to build relationships that foster change over an extended period.
Ephemeral projects are typically characterized by temporary gatherings and occupation of space. They create situations in which social interactions are momentary and not expected to become long-lasting. The immediate impact of ephemeral works often means they take place around a particular issue or concept. Protests, festivals, conferences, or pop-up performances have all been used as mediums for ephemeral social practice work.
Longitudinal projects are those built upon regular and reoccurring social interactions and dialogue, organized with the intention to be sustained over a longer period. They typically occupy the same space, and are characterized by deeper partnerships and relationships that are gradually built over the course of the work’s existence. As a result, many long-term social practice projects include a pedagogical element in their work. Classes, urban regeneration work, schools, or institutional partnerships are all examples of longitudinal projects.
== Social practice and institutions == Much social practice has taken place in the gap between the public and cultural institutions, which has been identified and acted upon as a new site for artistic intervention.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Living as Form, Socially Engaged Art from 1991-2011|last=Cruz|first=Teddy|publisher=Creative Time Books|year=2012|isbn=|editor-last=Thompson|editor-first=Nato|location=New York|pages=58|chapter=Democratizing Urbanization and the Search for a New Civic Imagination.}}</ref> However institutions, such as museums, foundations, non-profit organizations, and universities all play a significant role in supporting and amplifying social practice work. Many institutions constitute an extension of the public sphere, regardless of whether they are public or private in their ownership and operation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=[[Maves]] Mark|first=[[Hodal]] [[Stephanie]]|date=1999|title=Museums and Livable Communities|url=|journal=The Journal of Museum Education|volume=24|pages=5}}</ref> Partnerships between socially engaged art and contemporary institutions have thus widened the public sphere, and provided mutual benefits to the institution, the community, those engaged in the project, and the producers.
=== Social practice and the art market === In the traditional art world, market value and a work's collectability are deeply intertwined. This has posed a challenge to socially engaged artists seeking museum and gallery support, since many works go against the capitalist market to challenge traditional collecting practices.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Education for Socially Engaged Art|last=Helguera|first=Pablo|publisher=Jorge Pinto Books|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=4}}</ref> As a result, many socially engaged artists and producers must look elsewhere for support. The expansion of the art world in the 21<sup>st</sup> century has seen the emergence of alternative supports, such as non-profit organizations and the ever-growing biennale network.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The One and the Many: Contemporary Collaborative Art in a Global Context|last=Kester|first=Grant|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2011|isbn=|location=Durham|pages=126}}</ref> Other partners include art fairs, or commissions and residencies associated with universities, foundations, and urban regeneration.<ref>{{Cite book|title=What we Made: Conversations on art and social cooperation|last=Finkelpearl|first=Tom|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=Durham|pages=128}}</ref> Artists and producers have also formed their own means of support, as artist-run exhibition spaces, journals and blogs demonstrate.
=== Social practice in the university === Universities often partner with producers, artists and theorists of socially engaged art. These relationships offer mutual benefits for both academic institutions and artists. Universities offer artists employment security, the support and validation often required for establishing grant-based and corporate partnerships, and access to a high interdisciplinary environment that not only accepts, but encourages, experimentation. Artists in turn provide knowledge, skills and research to support individuals and broader programs within the university. As producers and scholars, they generate both new theory and new practice for the field of socially engaged art.
==Exhibitions and conferences==
Exhibitions of social practice art often include multiple artists or [[art collective]]s, and rather than exhibiting art objects, the artist’s participatory role in their work as well as their collaboration with the public becomes the exhibition.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/24/arts/design/outside-the-citadel-social-practice-art-is-intended-to-nurture.html</ref> Several conferences are held nationally and internationally to bring together artists and academics involved in the field. They have featured [[installation art|installation]], [[performance art]], [[film]], [[dance]], art talks, forums, and gallery exhibitions.

{{Infobox publisher | name = TAN Books | image = [[File:TANbooks ColorFF Dark.svg|200px]] | parent = [[Saint Benedict Press]] | status = | founded = 1967 | founder = Thomas A. Nelson | successor = | country = [[United States]] | headquarters = [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] | distribution = | keypeople = Conor Gallagher {{small|(President/CEO)}} | publications = [[Books]], [[Book]]lets, [[Prayer card]]s | topics = Catholicism | genre = | imprints = Confraternity of the Precious Blood
Neumann Press
American Chesterton Society | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|http://www.TANBooks.com}} }} '''TAN Books''' is a [[traditional Catholic]] American book distributor and publisher based in [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], [[North Carolina]]. ==History== TAN Books was founded in 1967, as "TAN Books and Publishers," in [[Rockford, Illinois]] by Thomas A. Nelson (not to be confused with the founder of the Bible-publishing firm [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]]) to keep in print books teaching the traditional Catholic faith in the wake of the upheaval in the Church that followed the [[Second Vatican Council]].{{cite web|title=About TAN|url=http://www.tanbooks.com/abouttan.htm|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19981206053705/http://www.tanbooks.com/abouttan.htm|archivedate=1998-12-06|df=}} The company's name was formed from the initials of its founder. Over the next 40 years, TAN published hundreds of new and classic titles on theology, Scripture, Church history, traditional devotions (including St. [[Louis de Montfort]]'s ''[[Secret of the Rosary]]'', printing more than 4 million copies), and the lives of the saints, many of which were reprints of titles published by such notable American Catholic publishers as [[Benziger Brothers]] and B. Herder Book Company. In 1971, TAN republished the [[Douay–Rheims Bible]], which had fallen out of print by the late 1960s, photographically reproducing it from the 1899 John Murphy & Co. edition. In the 1990s, with the advent of computer-based word processing, TAN began re-typesetting many of the titles in its catalog, rather than relying solely upon photographic reproductions of out-of-print works. In 2004, actor and director [[Mel Gibson]]'s [[Icon Productions]] granted TAN the license to publish the Catholic edition of ''The Passion: Photography from the Movie'' [[The Passion of the Christ]], a collection of photographs of scenes from the film accompanied with excerpts from the film's screenplay and quotations from the Douay–Rheims. Financial problems led TAN to file for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] protection in 2005. The company was subsequently acquired by [[Saint Benedict Press]] in 2008.[http://www.saintbenedictpress.com/ Saint Benedict Press] Following its acquisition, "TAN Books and Publishers" was renamed "TAN Books," with the "TAN" acronym now standing for ''Tuum Adoramus Nomen'' (Latin for "Let Us Adore Thy Name"). The company has aimed to improve the quality of its products by commissioning more aesthetically-pleasing covers, employing more durable book construction, and continuing to re-typeset numerous titles in its catalog. On October 31, 2018, TAN published its first foray into current affairs nonfiction, ''The Smoke of Satan: How Corrupt and Cowardly Bishops Betrayed Christ, His Church, and the Faithful . . . and What Can Be Done About It'' by Catholic journalist Philip F. Lawler, in response to the 2018 resurgence of [[Catholic Church sexual abuse cases|sexual abuse cases]] in the Church. TAN Books/Saint Benedict Press president and CEO Robert Gallagher, in his preface to the book, described the work as "the most difficult book we at TAN have published", as well as "one of the most important".{{cite book |last1=Lawler |first1=Philip F. |title=The Smoke of Satan: How Corrupt and Cowardly Bishops Betrayed Christ, His Church, and the Faithful . . . and What Can Be Done About It |date=2018 |publisher=TAN Books |location=Charlotte, NC |isbn=9781505113495 |page=vii}} ==Imprints== * '''TAN Books:''' Publishes reprints of classic Catholic works on theology, Scripture, traditional devotions, the [[Tridentine Mass]], and lives of the saints, as well as new titles on these subjects by contemporary authors and a line of newly-typeset [[Douay–Rheims Bible|Douay–Rheims Bibles]] (co-branded with Saint Benedict Press). In addition, the former "Saint Benedict Press Classics" series is now marketed under the "TAN Classics" moniker. TAN has also, in recent years, published resources aimed toward Catholic [[homeschooling]] families. * '''Confraternity of the Precious Blood:''' TAN currently serves as the distributor of reprints of classic works published by members of the Confraternity, such as ''My Daily Bread'' and ''My Imitation of Christ''. * '''Neumann Press:''' Acquired by TAN Books in 2013,{{Cite web| last = Jessica| title = Shower of Roses: Tan Books Acquires Neumann Press!| work = Shower of Roses| accessdate = 2016-07-03| date = 2013-10-23| url = http://showerofroses.blogspot.com/2013/10/tan-books-acquires-neumann-press.html}}{{Cite web| last = TAN Books| title = TAN Books Acquires Neumann Press| accessdate = 2016-07-03| url = http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/tan-books-acquires-neumann-press-228905321.html}} Neumann Press republishes classic Catholic children's works, history books, and novels aimed at students from primary to secondary school. * '''American Chesterton Society:''' Since May 2015, TAN Books has been the exclusive distributor of works published by the Society, which specializes in contemporary titles written in the tradition of Catholic philosopher [[G. K. Chesterton]]. ==Criticism== Since TAN's acquisition by Saint Benedict Press and the end of Nelson's involvement with the company, some traditionalist Catholics have expressed displeasure with TAN due to their perception that the company has abandoned its prior firmly-traditionalist editorial policy in favor of one intended to cater to conservative Catholics who, while doctrinally orthodox, accept the changes in Catholic practice that followed the Second Vatican Council. They cite, among others, the removal from TAN's catalog of works questioning the validity and/or rubrical integrity of the [[Mass of Paul VI]] (''The Great Sacrilege'' by Father James Wathen; ''Liturgical Time Bombs in Vatican II'' by [[Michael Davies (Catholic writer)|Michael Davies]]; ''[[Ottaviani Intervention|The Ottaviani Intervention]]'', translated with commentary by Father [[Anthony Cekada]]), works questioning the orthodoxy of the Council itself (''In the Murky Waters of Vatican II'' by Atila Sinke Guimarães), criticism of modern Bible translations (''Which Bible Should You Read?'' by Thomas A. Nelson), as well as works expressing Church teachings that, they claim, conflict with the post-conciliar emphases on [[Ecumenism (Catholic Church)|ecumenism]] and religious liberty.{{cn|date=August 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[List of book distributors]] ==External links== *[http://www.tanbooks.com/ TAN Books website] [[Category:Book publishing companies based in North Carolina]] [[Category:Catholic publishing companies]] [[Category:Catholic media]] [[Category:Christian publishing companies]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Book distributors]]

revision.text:
{{short description|A reserve to protect and conserve shipwrecks and historical resources in Lake Superior }} {{Infobox Protected area | name = Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve | iucn_category = | photo =SS_Comet_under_sail.jpg | photo_alt = | photo_caption = The ''Comet'' under sail. The only known treasure ship of Lake Superior, she sank in 1875 with 70 tons of silver ore.<ref name= "Evening News">{{cite news |last=Sundstrom |first=Shine |title=Comet only known treasure ship on bottom of lake |date= 23 July 1980 |page=4 |url=http://hermes.lssu.edu/~library/|newspaper= [[The Evening News (Sault Ste. Marie)|The Evening News]] |location=Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan|accessdate=8 March 2011}}</ref> | photo_width = 283 | map = USA Michigan | relief = 1 | map_alt = | map_caption = Location within the state of Michigan | map_width = 283 | mark = Red_pog.svg | marker_size = 10 | location = [[Lake Superior]], [[Chippewa County, Michigan|Chippewa County]], [[Luce County, Michigan]] USA | nearest_city = [[Emerson, Michigan]] | coordinates = {{coords|46.7772|-84.951|region:US-MI|display=inline, title}} | area = {{convert|376|sqmi|km2}} | established = 1987 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Michigan Department of Natural Resources]] | url = }} The '''Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve''' was established in 1987 to protect and conserve [[shipwrecks]] and historical resources on {{convert|376|sqmi|km2}} of [[Lake Superior]] bottomlands in [[Whitefish Bay]] and around [[Whitefish Point Light|Whitefish Point]], [[Michigan]]. The formation of the [[Michigan Underwater Preserves]] helped stop controversy over [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifact]] removal from shipwrecks of this area. The preserve is now known for deep, well preserved shipwrecks in clear water accessible to [[scuba divers]] with technical skill and experience. The preserve is one of the last places in the [[Great Lakes]] to observe shipwrecks without [[zebra mussel]] encrustation.
==History== Shipwrecks along the southern Lake Superior coast known as the “Graveyard of the Great Lakes” dramatically increased after the first [[Lock (water transport)|lock]] on the [[St. Marys River (Michigan–Ontario)|St. Marys River]] opened this coastline to shipping in 1855.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Allen |first1=Thomas |last2=Canfield |first2=Edward |title=Life on a Lonely Shore |page=3 |publisher=Lake Superior State University |location=Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan |year=2001 |edition=6th |origyear=First published 1991 |isbn=0-9706903-0-4}}</ref> Every vessel entering or leaving Lake Superior must pass Whitefish Point. The [[Whitefish Point Light]] first established in 1849 is arguably the most important light on Lake Superior.<ref name="Stonehouse">{{cite book |last=Stonehouse |first=Frederick |title=Lake Superior's Shipwreck Coast |pages=11–12, 176, 267|publisher=Avery Color Studios |location=Gwinn, Michigan |year=1998 |edition=6th |origyear=First published 1985 |isbn=0-932212-43-3}}</ref> More vessels have been lost in the Whitefish Point area than any other part of Lake Superior.<ref name="Stonehouse"/> Between the loss of the ''Invincible'' in 1816 and the sinking of the [[SS Edmund Fitzgerald|SS ''Edmund Fitzgerald'']] in 1975, the Whitefish Point area has claimed at least 240 ships.<ref name="Graveyard">{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=Mark L. |title=Graveyard of the Lakes |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tog_ll_MYrkC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=18 |publisher=Wayne State University Press |location=Detroit, Michigan |year=2000 |isbn=0-8143-3226-9 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> Vessels are funneled through Whitefish Bay [[downbound]] and [[downbound|upbound]] from the [[Soo Locks]]. Poor visibility from forest fire smoke, snow squalls, and Lake Superior’s notorious fogs had deadly consequences with the traffic congestion. Lake Superior’s {{convert|160|mi|km}} of open water and storms from the northwest can build immense seas with offshore waves of {{convert|30|ft|m}} or more. Such a storm sank the ''SS Edmund Fitzgerald'' {{convert|17|mi|km}} from Whitefish Point in 1975.<ref name="Stonehouse"/>
Sport diver Harrington reported that many of the shipwrecks of the Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve were "stripped of important [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] in the 1970s and early 1980s.<ref name="Harrington">{{cite book |author= Harrington, Steve |title= Divers Guide to Michigan |page= 321|publisher= Maritime Press & Great Lakes Diving Council, Inc. |location= St. Ignace, MI |year=1998|isbn=0-9624629-8-5}}</ref> The State of Michigan filed a lawsuit against the Great Lakes Shipwreck Historical Society (GLSHS) for illegal removal of artifacts from Great Lakes bottomlands.<ref name="Mighty Fitz">{{cite book |author= Schumacher, Michael |title= Mighty Fitz |pages= 158–159|publisher= Michigan Bloomsbury Publishing |location= New York & London |year=2005|isbn=1-58234-647-X }}</ref> The Michigan [[Michigan Department of Natural Resources and Environment|Department of Natural Resources]] (DNR) obtained a search warrant in 1992 and raided on the GLSHS’s offices and [[Great Lakes Shipwreck Museum]].<ref name="Mighty Fitz"/> The DNR found evidence the Shipwreck Society had:
{{quote|...removed about 150 artifacts from wrecks located on state-claimed bottomlands. … Shipwreck Society official [Tom Farnquist] described the Society’s actions as a kind of “damned if you do, damned if you don’t” puzzle. By preserving the artifacts for display at the Whitefish Point Museum, Farnquist reasoned the Society was really doing the state’s job for the DNR. DNR officer Carl TerHaar challenged Farnquist’s line of reasoning however. “The story we get is, ‘We’re taking stuff before somebody else does.’ That’s a never-ending excuse … saying we’ll take it before the next guy does. That’s like looting in the L.A. riots,” TerHaar commented.<ref>{{cite news |title= Shipwreck artifact dispute simmers |author=Storey, Jack|date= 4 December 1992|page= A1|url= http://hermes.lssu.edu/~library |newspaper= [[The Evening News (Sault Ste. Marie)|The Evening News]]|location=Sault Ste. Marie, MI|accessdate = 2010-08-07}}</ref>}}
Many of the artifacts removed from shipwrecks by the GLSHS without permits are displayed at the [[Great Lakes Shipwreck Museum]] at Whitefish Point by a settlement agreement with the state of Michigan.<ref name="Mighty Fitz"/><ref>{{cite book |last=MacInnis |first=Joseph |title=''Fitzgerald's'' Storm: The Wreck of the ''Edmund Fitzgerald'' |page=101 |publisher=Baker and Taylor, Inc. for Thunder Bay Press |location=Charlotte, North Carolina |year=1998 |isbn=1-882376-53-6}}</ref> The sport diving community raised a furious outcry over the disparity of special treatment for the museum divers who received no criminal prosecution while individual sport divers were prosecuted freely during the late 1980s and 1990s for removal of artifacts from shipwrecks. To this day many sport divers boycott the Great Lakes Shipwreck Museum.<ref name="Harrington"/>
==Preserve formation==
The Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve was established in 1987 to protect some of the region’s most sensitive underwater natural and cultural resources with the central objective to provide enhanced management of shipwrecks.<ref name="mpa.gov">{{cite web |title=NOAA -Marine Protected Areas of the United States, Michigan |url=http://www.mpa.gov/helpful_resources/states/michigan.html |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref> The Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve is administered through the [[Michigan Department of Environmental Quality]] Submerged Lands Program and the [[Michigan Department of History, Arts and Libraries]] of the Michigan Historical Center.<ref>{{cite web |title=Michigan Department of Environmental Submerged Lands Program |url=http://www.michigan.gov/deq/0,1607,7-135-3313_3677_3702---,00.html |accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Michigan Department of Arts Michigan Department of History, Arts, and Libraries Office of Archaeology Submerged Heritage |url=http://www.michigan.gov/hal/0,1607,7-160-17445_19273_19325-119740--,00.html|accessdate=10 November 2008}}</ref>
Scuba divers and history enthusiasts now help ensure the integrity of the preserve which is considered an underwater museum.<ref name="mpa.gov"/>
== Features ==
Many of the twenty-three known shipwrecks lying in depths from {{convert|30|ft|m}} to {{convert|270|ft|m}} are [[mooring (watercraft)|moored]] to protect the wrecks and enhance the safety of divers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve Resource|url=http://www.whitefishpoint.net/index.html|accessdate=29 November 2008}}</ref> The preserve has good visibility and offers deep water diving on a variety of shipwrecks. The preserve is one of the last places in the Great Lakes to observe shipwrecks without zebra mussel encrustation.<ref>{{cite web |title=A Diver's Guide to Michigan Underwater Preserves |year=2006–2007 |url=http://www.michiganpreserves.org/mupc_06proof.pdf|publisher= Michigan Underwater Preserve Council|location=St. Ignace, Michigan |accessdate=18 October 2009 |format=PDF}}</ref> [[Dry suit]]s are recommended due to cold temperatures and unprotected coves or bays. Most of the dive sites are deep and divers must be certain of their ability and their equipment before they attempt to dive in this preserve.<ref>Harrington, p. 321-322</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve Shipwrecks |- !width="120"|Site name !width="170"|Type !width="90"|Depth !width="190"|Coordinates !width="210"|Disaster History |- | ''Allegheny'' | Wood [[schooner]] | {{convert|30|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|46.016|N|85|10.601|W|name=Allegheny}} |Stranded at [[Crisp Point Light|Crisp Point]] in a gale on 6 June 1913. Crew rescued by [[Vermilion Point|Vermilion Point Life-saving Station]] crew with no loss of life.<ref name="Vessels Index">{{cite web |title=Great Lakes Vessels Online Index|url=http://ul.bgsu.edu/cgi-bin/xvsl2.cgi|accessdate=11 January 2009 |publisher=[[Bowling Green State University]]}}</ref><ref name="Shipwrecks">{{cite web|title=Shipwrecks Index|url=http://www.whitefishpoint.net/Shipwrecks/shipwrecks.html|accessdate=11 January 2009|publisher=Whitefish Point Underwater Preserve|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907124400/http://www.whitefishpoint.net/Shipwrecks/shipwrecks.html|archivedate=7 September 2008|df=}}</ref> |- | ''[[Comet (steamboat)|Comet]]'' | Wood [[propeller]] [[steamboat|steamer]] [[tug]] | {{convert|200|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|230|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|43.02|N|84|52.00|W|name=Comet}} |Sank 26 August 1875 after colliding with the ''Manitoba'' above [[Whitefish Point Light|Whitefish Point]] with the loss of ten lives.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve">{{cite web |title=Michigan Preserve|url=http://www.michiganpreserves.org/whitefish.htm|accessdate=11 January 2009 |publisher= Michigan Preserve Council}}</ref> |- | [[SS John B. Cowle (1902)|''John B. Cowle'']] | Steel propeller [[bulk freighter]] | {{convert|170|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|200|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|44.435|N|84|57.877|W|name=John B. Cowle}} |Sank 12 July 1909 in [[Whitefish Bay]] after colliding with the ''Isaac M. Scott'' with the loss of fourteen lives out of a twenty-four-man crew.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | [[SS M.M. Drake (1882)|''Drake'']] | Wood propeller bulk freighter | {{convert|40|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|50|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|46.588|N|85|05.933|W|name=Drake}} |Foundered 2 October 1901 off Vermilion Point, along with her tow, the schooner, ''Michigan''. Crew of both vessels were rescued by the propellers ''Northern Wave'' and ''Superior City'' with no loss of life.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Shipwrecks"/> |- | ''Eureka'' | Wood schooner [[barge]] | {{convert|50|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|55|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|50.15|N|85|10.76|W|name=Eureka}} |Disappeared 20 October 1886 after separating from the steamer ''Prentice'' {{convert|5.0|mi|km}} off Vermillion Point with the loss of all 6 crew members.<ref name="Shipwrecks"/> |- | ''Indiana'' | Wooden schooner barge | {{convert|100|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|115|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|48.66|N|085|17.16|W|name=Indiana}} |Sank 6 June 1858 {{convert|40|mi|km}}above Whitefish Point and {{convert|10.0|mi|km}} from shore with the crew of twenty-one taking to the life boats before she sank.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''Jupiter'' |Wooden schooner barge | | |Driven ashore near Vermilion Point 27 November 1872 in an arctic gale when the towline parted from steamer ''John A. Dix'' and the schooner ''Saturn''.<ref name="Shipwrecks"/><ref name="”Superior Shipwrecks">{{cite web |title= Lake Superior Shipwrecks|url=http://www.whimsea.net/shipwrecks_nov.htm|accessdate=16 January 2009 |publisher=htm Whim Sea}}</ref> |- | ''[[SS Samuel Mather (1887)|Samuel Mather]]'' | Wooden propeller | {{convert|140|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|170|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|34.308|N|084|42.325|W|name=Samuel Mather}} |Sank 21 November 1891 in a collision with the ''Brazil'' in off [[Point Iroquois Light|Point Iroquois]] in Whitefish Bay with no loss of life.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''John Mitchell'' | Steel freighter | {{convert|120|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|150|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|50.05|N|85|04.81|W|name=John Mitchell}} |Sank 10 July 1911 off Whitefish Point in a collision with ''William Henry Mack'' with the loss of three lives.<ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | [[Miztec (schooner barge)|''Miztec'']] | Wooden schooner barge | {{convert|45|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|55|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|48.073|N|85|04.500|W|name=Miztec}} |Foundered 13 May 1921 off Vermilion Point with the loss of all seven crew.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | [[SS Myron|''Myron'']] | Wooden propeller, [[lumber hooker]] | 45’ to 55’ | {{coord|46|48.463|N|85|01.646|W|name=Myron}} |Foundered {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} west of Whitefish Point on 23 November 1919 with barge ''Miztec'' in tow. Seventeen lives were lost from the ''Myron''. Only the Captain survived. He was picked up by the ''W.C. Franz'' when he was found drifting on wreckage near [[Ile Parisienne]].<ref name="Stonehouse"/><ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''Neshoto'' | Wood propeller | {{convert|45|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|55|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|49.173|N|85|07.488|W|name=Neshoto}} |Blinded from forest fire smoke, driven ashore and stranded {{convert|2.5|mi|km}} east of Crisp Point Light, crew rescued by Crisp Point Life Saving Crew.<ref name="Vessels Index"/> |- | ''Niagara'' | Wood schooner barge | {{convert|90|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|100|ft|m|0}} | {{coord|46|49.173|N|85|07.488|W|name=Niagara}} |Foundered 7 Sep 1887 after breaking tow from the steamer ''Australasia'' {{convert|7|mi|km}} northwest of Whitefish Point Light, all hands, 9 lives lost.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- |'' Alexander Nimick'' |Wood propeller |{{convert|100|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|45.743|N|85|12.982|W|name=Alexander Nimick}} |Pounded to pieces in {{convert|27|ft|m|0}} of water on 21 September 1907 after she was stranded on a sandbar near the mouth of the [[Two Hearted River]] with the loss of 6 lives. The 11 survivors made it to shore by lifeboat.<ref name="Shipwrecks"/> |- | ''Ora Endress S. S.'' |Fish tug |{{convert|13|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|15|ft|m|0}} | |Capsized and sank about {{convert|1|mi|km}} west of Whitefish Point. The Whitefish Point lighthouse keeper and 2 other men rescued all 11 crewmembers.<ref name="Shipwrecks"/> |- | ''[[John M. Osborn (steamboat)|John M. Osborn]]'' |Wooden propeller |{{convert|165|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|51.974|N|85|05.210|W|name=John M. Osborn}} |Sank 27 July 1884 in a collision with the ''Alberta'' {{convert|6|mi|km}} west-northwest of Whitefish Point with the loss of 3 lives.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''Panther'' |Wood propeller |{{convert|90|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|110|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|51.974|N|80|05.210|W|name=Panther}} |Sank 26 June 1916 in a collision in a fog with the ''James H. Hill'' off Parisienne Island in Whitefish Bay with no loss of life.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''Sadie Thompson'' |Wooden barge |{{convert|80|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|114|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|42.512|N|84|59.856|W|name=Sadie Thompson}} |Broke free and sank {{convert|1|mi|km}} south of Whitefish Point during the construction of the Harbor of Refuge in 1967.<ref name="Shipwrecks"/> |- | ''[[SS Sagamore (1892)|Sagamore]]'' |[[Whaleback]] barge |{{convert|45|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|65|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|45|31.089|N|84|37.927|W|name=Sagamore}} |Sank 29 July 1901 in a collision with propeller ''Northern Queen'' near Point Iroquois in Whitefish Bay with the loss of 2 lives.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''Saturn'' |Wood schooner barge |{{convert|20|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|45.952|N|85|01.547|W|name=Saturn}} |Pounded to pieces 27 November 1872 after grounding just west of Whitefish Point after breaking her towline with steam ''John A. Dix'' and sister ''Jupiter'' with the loss of 7 lives.<ref name="Shipwrecks"/> |- | ''[[Superior City]]'' |Steel freighter |{{convert|190|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|270|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|43.51|N|84|52.37|W|name=Superior City}} |Sank 20 August 1920 after her boilers exploded in a collision with steamer ''Willis L. King'' with the loss of 29 lives.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | [[SS Vienna (1873)|''Vienna'']] |Wood propeller |{{convert|120|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|148|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|44.46|N|84|57.91|W|name=Vienna}} |Sank 17 September 1873 after a collision with propeller ''Nipigon'' about {{convert|4|mi|km}} below Whitefish Point with no loss of life.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |- | ''Zillah'' |Wood propeller |{{convert|230|ft|m|0}} to {{convert|250|ft|m|0}} |{{coord|46|43.75|N|84|54.97|W|name=Zillah}} |Foundered {{convert|4|mi|km}} off Whitefish Point 29 August 1926. Her crew of 14 were rescued by the [[U.S. Coast Guard]] and the ''William B. Schiller''.<ref name="Vessels Index"/><ref name="Michigan Preserve"/> |}
